Step.name: The Evolving Role of the Soil Scientist
Step.html: Soil scientists from every district, forest, and region are experiencing a shift in their work from responding to project proposals to being a key player in project proposal design, implementation, and monitoring.

Step.name: Soil Resource Objectives
Step.html: Soil Resource Objectives can vary from site to site due to the tremendous variability of our nation's soils.

Step.name: Assessment
Step.html: Pre-treatment assessment is conducted using the FSDMP to monitor forest sites for physical attributes that could influence site resilience and long-term sustainability before ground-disturbing management activities.

Step.name: Monitoring
Step.html: Post-treatment monitoring is conducted on representative sites that the soil scientist, district ranger, line-officer, or forest supervisor feels is important to review to assess the success of management activities in meeting legal, regulatory, and policy objectives. By using a consistent monitoring approach, forests in every Forest Service Region can build soil resource programs to meet their specific requirements in accordance with their soil quality standards and guidelines.

Step.name: IDT-Healty Forests
Step.html: The interdisciplinary team is challenged to define what a healthy forest looks like on each unique project whether it involves mechanical thinning, prescribed burning, watershed restoration, range management, fire recovery, or roads analysis. The soil scientist must be equipped with information on the soil resource to help define resource objectives, management practices, identify Best Management Practices and describe the desired condition.

Step.name: NEPA
Step.html:
NEPA - Existing and Desired Condition

As an active team player, the soil scientist clearly communicates opportunities, concerns, and limitations based on sound pre-assessment evaluation of the soil resource. Using the Forest Soil Disturbance Monitoring Protocol (FSDMP) to evaluate physical soil disturbances enables the soil scientist to determine site resilience and long-term sustainability and hydrologic function. Monitor the attributes of surface cover, ruts, compaction, and platy structure can also be used to generate best management practices that help maintain site productivity. Together the IDT can find solutions and develop a well-articulated proposed action.

Step.name: Implementation Monitoring
Step.html:
Implementation Monitoring with Contracting Officers Representative,, Sale Administrator, Harvest Inspector

Once a project has completed the environmental assessment phase and moves into implementation, the soil scientist can work with the COR, SA, and HI to communicate desired conditions established through the NEPA document. Using the Soil Disturbance Field Guide (SDFG), the soil scientist can ensure that everyone understands the definitions of different soil attributes from displacement to compaction. Soil disturbance class photographs from across the country can be shown to illustrate what a certain disturbance class looks like. SA's and Harvest inspectors and purchasers can complete the SDFG field monitoring sheet to get a quick idea of if the desired condition was obtained.
